subject: Re: [junit] Missing API: Assert.assertThat(boolean) or 	IsCollection.isEmpty()
msgSnippet: ... Excellent!  At last. To be clear, my proposal was a single syntax that would allow hamcrest-style assertions from a boolean method on any non-final class,
messageBody:
On Sat, May 16, 2009 at 6:53 AM, Steve Freeman <smgfreeman@...> wrote:
> On 14 May 2009, at 15:45, David Saff wrote:
>> Let me take this in a different direction.  I've wanted, for a while,
>> to be able to say
>>
>> assertThat(list).isEmpty();
>>
>> Using imposterization, this is possible to write, and gives the
>> wonderful bonus that failure messages can be hamcrest-level
>> informative, like:
>>
>> Expected: x.isEmpty()
>> Actual: x = [a, b, c]
>
>
> in the new candidate version of Hamcrest, try
>
> assertThat(list, is(empty());
>
> gives
>
> java.lang.AssertionError:
> Expected: is an empty collection
>      got: <[one, three]>

Excellent! At last.

To be clear, my proposal was a single syntax that would allow
hamcrest-style assertions from a boolean method on any non-final
class, including:

assertThat(list).isEmpty();
assertThat(list).equals(list2);
assertThat(list).contains(item);
assertThat(file).exists();
assertThat(objectStreamField).isPrimitive();

The _big_ blocker for this idea is that String is final, meaning that
there's no way to use the same syntax to get this to compile:

assertThat("abc").contains("c");

David Saff
